sponge and NiCo2S4@CS catalyst (a); survey spectrum (b) and high-resolution XPS spectra of C 1 s (c), S 2p (d), Ni 2p (e) and Co 2p (f) of NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM images (a, b, c), TEM images (d, e) and SAED pattern (f) of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst; EDS mapping of C (h), Ni (i), Co (j), S (k) and the corresponding SEM image (g). Fig 2 Fig. 3 CV curves of the NiCo2S4@CS catalysts with different Ni:Co ratios in the hydrothermal process (a); CV curves recorded under the conditions of absence and presence of urea (b); CV curves tested in x M KOH + 0.2 M urea (x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) (c) and 5 M KOH + x M urea (x = 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) (d); CV curves of different electrodes tested in 5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea (e) and CA curves of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst recorded in 5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea at different potentials (0.3, 0.4 and 0.5 V) (f). Scan rate: 20 mV s−1 under room temperature. Fig 3 Fig. 4 LSV curves of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst recorded at different scan rates (0.05–1.00 V s−1) in 5 M KOH + 0.04 M urea (a) and the corresponding relationship of E p vs. lnν (b) and j p vs. ν 1/2 (c). Tafel plots of the NiCo2S4@CS and NiCo-precursor@CS catalysts in 5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 (d). Fig 4 Fig. 5 CV curves of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst recorded at different scan rates within a non-Faraday potential window (−0.30 V ∼ −0.20 V) in 5 M KOH (a) and plots of anodic current density at −0.25 V against scan rates of the NiCo-precursor@CS and NiCo2S4@CS catalysts (b); CA curves of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst tested under different temperatures at 0.4 V in 5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea (c) and the corresponding Arrhenius plots (d). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Nyquist plots of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst under the conditions of presence and absence of urea (a); Nyquist plots recorded at different potentials in 5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea (b); Nyquist plots comparison of NiCo-precursor@CS and NiCo2S4@CS catalyst at 0.4 V in 5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea (c); Nyquist plots fitting and the corresponding equivalent circuit (d). Frequency range: 100 kHz–10 mHz. AC amplitude of EIS: 10 mV. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Discharge polarization curves and power density curves of DUHPFC with different anodes (a); discharge polarization curves and power density curves recorded at different potentials (b); stability research at different temperatures (c) of the NiCo2S4@CS anode assembled DUHPFC. Flow rate: 10 mL min−1. Anolyte: 5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea. Catholyte: 2 M H2SO4 + 1 M H2O2. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Adsorption geometries of OH− (a) and urea (b) on the surface of carbon sponge; Adsorption geometries of OH− (c) and urea (d) on the surface of NiCo2S4; Charge density difference plots of OH− (e) and urea (f) on NiCo2S4 (green and blue represent the electron gain and depletion, respectively). Urea oxidation is a significant reaction for utilizing urea-rich wastewater or human urine as sustainable power sources which can ease the water eutrophication while generate electricity. A direct urea-hydrogen peroxide fuel cell is a new kind of fuel cell employing urea as fuel and hydrogen peroxide as oxidant which possesses a larger cell voltage. Herein, this work tries to promote the kinetics process of urea oxidation by preparing low-cost and high-efficient NiCo2S4 nanowires modified carbon sponge electrode. The carbon sponge used in this work with a similar three-dimensional multi-channel structure to Ni foam, is prepared by carbonizing recycled polyurethane sponge which is also a process of recycling waste. The performance of the prepared catalyst in an alkaline solution is investigated in a three-electrode system. With the introduction of Co element to the catalyst, a reduced initial urea oxidation potential and a high performance are obtained. Furthermore, a direct urea-hydrogen peroxide fuel cell is assembled using the NiCo2S4 nanowires modified carbon sponge anode. Results indicate that the prepared catalyst provides a chance to solve the current problems that hinder the development of urea electrooxidation (high initial urea oxidation potential, low performance, and high electrode costs). Graphical abstract A low-cost NiCo2S4 nanowires modified 3D carbon sponge is prepared and applied to a novel direct urea-hydrogen peroxide fuel cell which proposes a new method for treating wastewater containing urea. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon sponge Direct urea fuel cell Electrocatalyst NiCo2S4 nanowires Urea oxidation 1 Introduction Nowadays, the discharge of wastewater from fertilizer plants and human or animal urine which contains different concentrations of urea has caused serious water entrophication. Treating the urea in wastewater and urine becomes an urgent problem. Traditional methods to decompose urea are usually biological decomposition, chemical oxidation, and enzymatic decomposition [1–3]. However, these methods always need complex equipment and high temperature conditions which restrict their long term and large scale application for urea decomposition. Urea oxidation is a new method to treat the urea in wastewater and urine. At the same time, if urea oxidation can be applied to a direct urea fuel cell, it can produce electricity while treating the wastewater containing urea which may be a new opportunity to ease the energy crisis. By far, the most studied direct urea cells (DUFC) always employ oxygen as oxidant [4,5]. The voltage of DUFC using oxygen as oxidant is 1.15 V, which is a smaller value than those of direct methanol fuel cells (1.21 V) [6] and hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells (1.24 V) [7]. Direct urea hydrogen peroxide fuel cell (DUHPFC) is a new kind of fuel cell using urea as fuel and H2O2 as oxidant. According to Eqs. (1–3), it can be seen that the theoretical voltage of DUHPFC is 2.51 V, which shows large application possibilities [8]. As we all know, anode is an important component of a fuel cell. The activity of anode catalysts has significant influence on the whole cell performance. (1) Anode : CO ( N H 2 ) 2 + 6 KOH → N 2 + C O 2 + 5 H 2 O + 6 K + + 6 e − E θ = − 0.75 V (2) Cathode : H 2 O 2 + H 2 S O 4 + 2 e − → 2 H 2 O + S O 4 2 − E θ = 1.76 V (3) Overall : CO ( N H 2 ) 2 + 3 H 2 O 2 + 6 KOH + 3 H 2 S O 4 → N 2 + C O 2 + 11 H 2 O + 3 K 2 S O 4 Δ E θ = 2.51 V Recent years, many efforts have been made to improve the performance of the catalysts towards urea oxidation. Noble metal catalysts exhibited high performance for oxidizing many conventional fuels [9], but they show poor activity towards urea oxidation [10,11]. Many studies have focused on replacing noble metal electrodes with low-cost, high-performance alternative electrodes. Currently, nickel-based catalysts are widely considered as the superior catalytic activity catalyst for urea electrooxidation [12,13]. However, due to the high initial oxidation potential of urea oxidation and easily CO-poisoning behavior on nickel-based catalysts, it is still a long way to go for commercial applications [12,14]. There is a common sense that the microstructure has a significant influence on the performance of the catalyst. Thus, nickel nanowires [15,16], highly porous nickel [17], nickel nanoribbons [18] and nickel nanosheets [19–21] catalyst have been researched towards urea oxidation, and all of these catalysts showed good performance. King [22] proposed that the initial oxidation potential can be lowered by introducing transition metal (such as Co, Fe, Zn) into the catalyst. Up to now, a series of Ni-based bimetallic catalysts including Ni–Mo [23], Ni–Zn [24] and Ni-Co [12,16,25] have been prepared to achieve a low initial oxidation potential of urea. At the same time, some novel support materials like metal foam [26,27], Ti mesh [28], stainless steel mesh [29] and carbon nanotube [30,31] are employed to increase the specific surface area of the catalyst. For commercial applications, the high costs of these novel support materials also should be taken into consideration. Therefore, reduce the cost of catalyst is as important as to improve the performance of the catalyst and lower the initial oxidation potential of urea. Although many works have been reported to catalyze the electrooxidation of urea, there have been limited reports on its application to direct urea fuel cells (DUFC). Also the limited application of DUFC has aroused doubts that whether the oxidation of urea, which usually has an initial oxidation potential of up to 0.2 to 0.4 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), is feasible as an anode reaction in a fuel cell. Herein, this work tries to solve the existed problems of normal performance, high initial urea oxidation potential, and high costs of the anode catalyst in DUFC. Polyurethane sponges are often used as fillers in automobiles, furniture, and other industries. However, polyurethane sponges are difficult to degrade naturally, which may cause environmental pollution. In this work, we use recycled polyurethane sponge to prepare low-cost carbon sponge support material with a three-dimensional multi-channel structure, which is similar to Ni foam. The NiCo2S4 nanowires were successfully grown on the surface of 3D carbon sponge by a simple two-step hydrothermal method, which exhibited a large specific surface area and a large number of active sites. The performance of the prepared catalyst towards urea oxidation was investigated by electrochemical analysis. In addition, as an efficient anode catalyst for urea oxidation, it was further researched in a direct urea-hydrogen peroxide fuel cell. We believe this work designed a highly efficient and low-cost anode electrocatalyst for direct urea fuel cell. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of carbon sponge Firstly, 2 g oxalic acid was added into 40 mL of furfuryl alcohol solution with stirring until completely dissolved. A piece of recycled polyurethane sponge was immersed in the above solution for 10 min and then the adsorbed liquid was squeezed out. The treated polyurethane sponge was dried at 100 °C in a vacuum oven for 1 h. After that, the treated sponge was put into a tube furnace and annealed at 800 °C under the protection of Ar gas (heating rate: 2 °C/min). After carbonized at 800 °C for 1 h, the aimed carbon sponge (CS) was obtained. 2.2 Preparation of NiCo2S4@cs catalyst To prepare the NiCo2S4@CS electrode, a piece of carbon sponge (1 cm × 1 cm × 1 mm) was firstly pre-treated with concentrated HCl, deionized water and dried at 60 °C for 1 h. The pre-treated carbon sponge was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave containing 0.04 M Co(NO3)2•⋅6H2O, 0.02 M Ni(NO3)2•⋅6H2O, 0.072 M NH4F, and 0.072 M urea. After heated at 120 °C for 12 h, the obtained electrode was washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times which was named as NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst. Then, the obtained NiCo-precursor@CS was further treated in 0.4 M Na2S at 120 °C for 10 h in the same Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. After this sulfurization process, the obtained electrode was named as NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. For comparison, electrodes with different concentration ratios of Ni and Co (Ni:Co = 0:3, 1:2, 2:1, 3:0) in the hydrothermal process were also prepared. The preparation method of the cathode catalyst (Pd/Ti plate electrode) used in the fuel cell can be founded in our previous work [32]. 2.3 Characterizations The morphology of the prepared catalyst was investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-6480) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) equipped with Cu-Kα radiation source (λ=0.1514 nm) was adopted to confirm the crystal structure of the electrode. Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) as well as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the chemical composition of surface species of the NiCo2S4@CS electrode. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical measurements were conducted in a three-electrode system, which employs a Ag/AgCl (KClstd) electrode as reference electrode and a platinum electrode (Type 213) as counter electrode. Cyclic voltammetry (CV), chronoamperometry (CA), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were employed to study the electrochemical behavior of the prepared electrode. To verify the performance of the assembled DUHPFC, cell polarization curve and power density curves were tested by battery test system (CT-1004-5V-3A). The effective working area of the fuel cell is 1 cm × 1 cm. During the electrochemical tests, the current density (A cm−2) is refers to the geometric area of the electrode. 2.5 Computational details First-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using CASTEP module in Materials Studio [33–36]. The exchange and correlation energies were described using OTFG ultrasoft pseudopotential and Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) approximation. The electron-ion interactions were calculated within a plane-wave basis set with an energy cutoff of 400 eV. The NiCo2S4 (311) surface slab was created by firstly cleaving a conventional cell, followed by adding a 15 Å vacuum layer to avoid undesired interaction between neighboring cells, and finally expanded into a 1 × 2 × 1 supercell. The carbon sponge was modeled using a graphene sheet containing 32 carbon atoms. The convergence tests of the total energy with respect to k-points sampling and energy-cutoff were carefully examined, using 1 × 1 × 1 for NiCo2S4 (311) surface and 2 × 2 × 1 for carbon surface slabs as well as with adsorbates. Ionic relaxations were carried out using a conjugate gradient algorithm till the net force on all individual atoms was less than 0.05 eV Å−1, and the SCF tolerance was set to 1 × e − 5 eV atom−1 for geometry optimization. The binding energies (E ads) for OH− (or urea) on NiCo2S4 (or carbon) surface were determined using the following equation: (4) E ads = E total − E surf . − E mol . where E total is total energy the system containing both NiCo2S4 (or carbon) surface with adsorbed OH− (or urea), E surf. is the energy of clean NiCo2S4 (or carbon) surface, and E mol. is the energy of a free OH− (or urea) molecule in vacuum. During E ads calculations, van der Waals interactions were also considered. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization Fig. 1 (a) displayed the XRD pattern of the prepared carbon sponge and the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. The wide characteristic diffraction peak appeared on the carbon sponge sample at 25° can be attributed to the (002) lattice plane of carbon [37,38]. For the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst sample, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 16.3°, 26.8°, 31.6°, 38.3°, 47.4°, 50.5°, and 55.3° are related to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511) and (440) lattice planes of NiCo2S4 (JCPDS No. 20-0782), respectively. Besides, the wide diffraction peak of (002) lattice plane of the carbon matrix is also observed. This result indicates that NiCo2S4 nanowires were successfully grown on the 3D carbon sponge skeleton. The XPS spectra of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst were posted in Fig. 1(b–f). The full scan survey spectrum (Fig. 1(b)) reveals that Co, Ni, S, O, and C were contained in the sample. High-resolution spectra of these elements were shown to verify the specific composition of the surface species on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. Fig. 1(c) displays that the C 1 s spectrum can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 284.6, 285.8 and 288.4 eV, which are associated to sp 2 CC, sp 3 C-C and CO bond, respectively [39]. The S 2p spectrum was deconvoluted into three peaks and a satellite peak, as exhibited in Fig. 1(d). Peaks at 161.8 and 163.1 eV can be attributed to the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 binding energies, which proved the existence of S2− [40]. The peak at 163.9 eV is a characteristic binding energy of a metal-sulfur (M-S) bond, which may be attributed to the Ni–Co–S phase that consistent with the XRD results [40]. Fig. 1(e) is the Ni 2p spectrum which displayed two spin-orbit doublets (Ni 2p 3/2: 855.6 eV; and Ni 2p 1/2: 873.1 eV) and two shakeup satellites (861.8 and 880.4 eV) [41]. The binding energy difference of 17.5 eV between these two spin-orbit doublets suggests the presence of Ni2+ and Ni3+ in the catalyst, and the intense satellite peaks indicate that Ni2+ is the main component [42,43]. Similarly, the Co 2p spectrum was deconvoluted into six peaks. Two characteristic binding energies of 780.5 and 795.9 eV correspond to Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2, respectively [43]. The binding energy difference of two peaks (15.4 eV) also indicated the presence of Co2+ and Co3+ species on the surface of NiCo2S4@CS catalyst, in which Co3+ is the majority [43,44]. These results are consistent with XRD results. SEM was performed to characterize the morphology of the prepared NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the prepared carbon sponge maintained a 3D open multi-channel structure, which is similar to Ni foam. This kind of morphology makes carbon sponge a superior matrix because of the large specific surface area, good electrical conductivity, and low price. The enlarged view of Fig. 2(b, c) implies that one-dimension NiCo2S4 nanowires were successfully grown on the carbon sponge skeleton. NiCo2S4@CS catalyst exhibited a rougher surface when compared to the morphology of NiCo-precursor@CS electrode in Fig. S1(a–c) (supporting information). This rough surface is conducive to providing more active catalytic sites. Also, this kind of nanowire array morphology significantly increased the specific surface area of the electrode and promoted the contact between the solution and the active catalyst. Fig. S1(d–f) displayed the SEM images of NiCo2S4@CS catalyst after performance tests. It indicates that the obtained nanowires array on NiCo2S4@CS catalyst is stable, which also predicted a good stability of the prepared catalyst. Fig. 2(d) and (e) is the TEM images of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. According to the diameter distribution of the NiCo2S4 nanowires (Fig. S8), the diameters of the nanowires range from 7 to 28 nm and the average diameter is 18.8 nm. And a lattice spacing of 2.83 Å is obtained in Fig. 2(e), which can be indexed to the (311) lattice plane of NiCo2S4 (JCPDS No. 20-0782). This result proved the existence of NiCo2S4 nanowires again. Fig. 2(f) is the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. Three obvious rings with d-spacing of 2.83, 2.35, and 1.66 Å correspond to the (311), (400) and (440) lattice planes of NiCo2S4 (JCPDS No.20–0782), respectively. These results are consistent with the strong characteristic diffraction peaks of (311), (400), (440) lattice plane in XRD patterns. Fig. 2(h–k) is the EDS mapping of C, Ni, Co and S elements and Fig. 2(g) is the corresponding SEM image. These images indicate the uniform distribution of Ni, Co, S, and C elements on the surface of NiCo2S4 catalyst. 3.2 Study on the electrochemical behavior of the NiCo2S4@CS electrode A series of reference catalysts were prepared by varying the concentration ratio of Ni and Co in the hydrothermal process to investigate the influence of different composition ratios of Ni and Co on the performance of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. The CV curves of these catalysts were tested in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea (Fig. 3 (a)). Results indicate that the catalyst with the concentration ratio of Ni:Co=1:2 (NiCo2S4@CS catalyst) in the hydrothermal process shows the highest current density towards the electrooxidation of urea. Also, the initial oxidation potential of urea was negatively moved from 0.33 to 0.14 V with the change of the ratio of Ni:Co. The lowest initial oxidation potential is also achieved on the catalyst of Ni:Co=1:2. Fig. 3(b) is the comparison of CV curves under the conditions of absence and presence of urea in the solution. With the presence of urea, a much higher current density is caused by the electrooxidation of urea [45]. This result implies that the prepared NiCo2S4@CS catalyst possesses a specific catalytic performance towards urea oxidation. The influence of KOH concentration on the performance of the prepared catalyst is shown in Fig. 3(c). The current density increased from 260 to 673 mA cm−2 at 0.5 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), with the increase of KOH concentration from 1 to 6 M. However, adjusting KOH concentration from 5 to 6 M, the increase of current density is minimal [41]. Combining the increase in KOH concentration and the limited increase of current density, we believe that 5 M KOH is a suitable concentration. Also, the initial oxidation potential of urea exhibited regularly move to a more negative potential, which implies the faster kinetics process at a higher KOH concentration [46]. Fig. 3(d) shows the influence of urea concentration on the performance of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. The current density was 318 mA cm−2 in 0.1 M urea, and it was further increased to 635 mA cm−2 in 0.2 M urea at 0.5 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) under natural diffusion. However, current density recorded in 0.3 M urea was decreased to 553 mA cm−2. The lower performance in 0.3 M urea may be caused by the competition coverage between urea molecules and the increased gas products (N2 and CO2) caused by the accelerated urea oxidation reaction on the surface of the catalyst in a higher urea concentration. Results show that the prepared catalyst exhibited the highest performance towards urea oxidation in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea. CV curves of carbon sponge, NiCo-precursor@CS, and NiCo2S4@CS recorded in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea at 20 mV s−1 were displayed in Fig. 3(e). The carbon sponge shows no catalytic performance towards urea electrooxidation, and it was employed as a superior support material in this work. The NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst shows a noticeable catalytic performance and the current density is 298 mA cm−2 at 0.5 V, while NiCo2S4@CS catalyst exhibited the best performance among these three electrodes. Results imply that sulfurization is an effective method to improve the performance of Ni-Co bimetallic electrode for the catalysis of urea oxidation [15]. Because after sulfurization, NiCo2S4 possesses a much higher conductivity due to the lower band gap which will accelerate the transfer of electrons and then improve the performance of NiCo2S4@CS catalyst toward urea electrooxidation. In addition, to investigate the catalyst performance when using 2D support, Ti foil was employed to build an electrode of NiCo2S4@Ti foil through the same hydrothermal method and its performance in 5 mol L−1 KOH and 0.2 mol L−1 urea was compared with NiCo2S4@CS electrode shown in Fig. S6. CA curves of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst tested in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea at different potentials were shown in Fig. 3(f). The rapid decline of the current density at the start of the test can be attributed to the rapid consumption of urea molecules nearby the catalyst surface [47], followed with a mass transfer controlled process. Current density has dropped by 5.7% on the CA curves from 300 s to 1800s at 0.3 V. And the values are 7.3% and 8.6% at 0.4 V and 0.5 V, respectively. The acceptable decline of current density implies a good stability of the prepared NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. 3.3 Study on kinetic parameters of urea electrooxidation on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst LSV curves recorded in a low urea concentration (0.04 M) under different scan rates were tested to investigate the kinetic parameters of urea electrooxidation on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. It is worth to note that two current density peaks exhibited on the LSV curves of both NiCo2S4@CS (Fig. 4 (a)) and NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst (Fig. S3), which could not be observed on the CV curves in a solution of high urea concentration. Peak A is related to the further oxidation reaction of Ni2+/Ni3+ and Co2+/Co3+ [48] and Peak B can be attributed to a diffusion-controlled urea electrooxidation reaction in a solution of low urea concentration. Fig. 4(b) exhibited the relationship between the peak potential (E p) and the logarithmic of scan rate (lnν) obtained from LSV curves. The peak potential moves to a positive potential with the increase of scan rate, which reveals that urea electrooxidation is an irreversible electrochemical process [14]. Besides, the anodic charge transfer coefficient (α) of urea oxidation on both NiCo2S4@CS and NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst can be estimated from the following equation [49]: (5) E p = ( 0.013 α n 0 ) × ln ν + constant Based on Eq. (5), the anodic charge transfer coefficient (α) was estimated to be 0.59 and 0.52 on the NiCo2S4@CS and NiCo-precursor@CS catalysts, respectively. Fig. 4(c) shows the relationship between the peak current density (j p) and the square root of scan rate (ν 1/2) derived from Fig. 4(a). Thus, the diffusion coefficient of urea (D urea) was obtained using Eq. (6) [49]: (6) j p = 2.99 × 10 5 [ ( 1 − α ) n 0 ] 1 / 2 A n C urea D urea 1 / 2 ν 1 / 2 where α is anodic charge transfer coefficient, n 0 is the number of electrons involved in the rate-determining step (n 0=1), A is a geometric area of the catalyst, C urea is the urea concentration (mol cm−3), n is the number of transferred electrons of urea oxidation (n = 6), and ν is scan rate (V s−1). According to the slope of j p vs. ν 1/2 displayed in Fig. 4(c), the diffusion coefficient of urea was 1.57 × 10−5 cm2 s−1 and 6.48 × 10−6 cm2 s−1 on the NiCo2S4@CS and NiCo-precursor@CS catalysts, respectively. This obtained value (1.57 × 10−5 cm2 s−1) of D urea on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst is higher than those reported ones of Ni(OH)2/C-EG catalyst (3.76 × 10−9 cm2 s−1) [14], NiO/graphene (3.39 × 10−9 cm2 s−1), NiO/MWCNTs (7.69 × 10−10 cm2 s−1) [50], nickel electrode (0.85 × 10−5 cm2 s−1) [51] and Ni(OH)2/PPy/GO/GCE catalyst (9.2 × 10−10 cm2 s−1) [52]. The higher diffusion coefficient of urea can be attributed to the special morphology of NiCo2S4 nanowires that contributed a large specific surface area for the urea electrooxidation. Also, the D urea of NiCo2S4@CS catalyst is 2.4 times higher than NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst. Tafel plots obtained under quasi-steady-state of urea oxidation at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 are employed to evaluate the catalytic kinetics of the prepared catalysts. In Fig. 4(d), the values of Tafel slope were 72.8 and 80.1 mV dec−1 of NiCo2S4@CS and NiCo-precursor@CS. The lower value implies that NiCo2S4@CS catalyst is more sensitive to the over-potential, namely, a higher performance caused by the improved charge transfer rate and faster kinetics towards urea oxidation [53]. Also, the value of 72.8 mV dec−1 is lower than or comparable to some reported ones of Ni(OH)2/C-EG (79.13 mV dec−1), Ni(OH)2/C-EGNB (82.97 mV dec−1) [14], NiO/Gt (98.51 mV dec−1) [49] and mesoporous Ni–P catalyst (81 mV dec−1) [54]. Besides, the exchange current density (j 0) could be obtained from the regression equation of Tafel plots, and the values were estimated to be 5.16 × 10−6 A cm−2 and 2.69 × 10−6 A cm−2 for NiCo2S4@CS and NiCo-precursor@CS catalysts, respectively. The higher value of j 0 proved the faster kinetics towards urea oxidation on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst again [49]. The kinetic parameters of urea electrooxidation on both catalysts were exhibited in Table 1 . 3.4 Electrochemical active surface area of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst Electrochemical active surface area (EASA) of the prepared catalyst plays an important role in the catalytic performance. CV curves recorded under different scan rates in 5 M KOH at a non-Faraday potential window (−0.30 V ∼ −0.20 V) were shown in Figs. 5 (a) and S4. The EASA of nanomaterials is related to the double layer capacitance (C d), and it can be evaluated from the slope of anodic current density (j) vs. scan rate (ν) in Fig. 5(b) [55,56] according to Eqs. (7) and (8) [57,58]: (7) d j = C d · d ν (8) EASA = C d / C * Where j is the anodic current (mA), ν is the scan rate (mV s−1) and C* is the specific theoretical double layer capacitance of Ni electrode in an alkaline electrolyte and the value is 60 µF cm−2 [59]. The double layer capacitances (C d) of NiCo-precursor@CS and NiCo2S4@CS catalyst were 5.77 mF cm−2 and 19.84 mF cm−2 respectively. Thus, the EASA estimated by Eq. (8) was 330.7 cm2 for the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst with a geometry area of 1.0 cm × 1.0 cm at −0.25 V which is almost 3.4 times larger than the value of the NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst. It is worth to note that obtained EASA on both catalysts is not an absolute value, but a relative value, and this value may affect by the potential or alkaline concentration and other conditions. The improvement of EASA on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst indicates that sulfurization is an effective method to exposure more active sites. 3.5 Activation energy of urea electrooxidation on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst CA curves of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst tested in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea under different temperatures (Fig. 5(c)) were recorded to determine the apparent activation energy (E a) of urea electrooxidation on the prepared catalyst. CA curves reveal that temperature has a great influence on the catalyst performance towards urea electrooxidation. The better performance at a higher temperature was attributed to the enhanced reaction kinetics at higher temperatures. The value of E a could be calculated from the slope of lnj vs. 1/T in Fig. 5(d) according to Arrhenius formula (Eq. (9)) [59]. (9) ∂ ln j ∂ T = − E a R T 2 where T is the temperature (K), j is the corresponding current density (mA cm−2), and R is molar gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1). Arrhenius plots of lnj vs. 1/T were constructed for both NiCo-precursor@CS and NiCo2S4@CS catalysts in Fig. 5(d). The linear relationship between lnj and 1/T indicates that urea electrooxidation on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst surface is partially activation controlled [60]. The apparent activation energy of urea electrooxidation on the prepared catalyst at 0.4 V was 15.3 kJ mol−1. Also, the E a of urea electrooxidation on the NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst was researched in the same way (Fig. S4), and the value is 16.8 kJ mol−1. The smaller E a on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst also implies that the electrooxidation of urea is easier to occur on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. 3.6 Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy analysis of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst Nyquist plots of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst were tested to further probe the catalytic performance of urea electrooxidation. Fig. 6 (a) is the Nyquist plots of NiCo2S4@CS catalyst recorded under the conditions of absence and presence of urea at 0.4 V. There is a semicircle that appeared in the high-frequency on the Nyquist plots in both situation, which is associated with the conversion of Ni2+ to Ni3+ and Co3+ to Co4+ [61]. The semicircle in the low-frequency region in the presence of urea could be attributed to the response of direct oxidation of urea on the catalyst [62]. Nyquist plots performed in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea at different potentials were displayed in Fig. 6(b). It reveals that higher polarization potential is helpful to decrease the electrochemical impedance of urea electrooxidation. And these Nyquist plots were fitted by ZSimDemo software. The fitting results and the equivalent circuit were exhibited in Fig. 6(d). R s is the solution resistance between the catalyst and reference electrode. Parallel connected faradaic impedance (R ct1) and constant phase element (Q 1) are associated with the chemical oxidation process of Co and Ni elements, while R ct2 (electrochemical impedance) and Q 2 (constant phase element) are related to direct oxidation of urea on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst [62]. Q 1-Yo and Q 2-Yo represent the admittance of Q 1 and Q 2. Q 1-n and Q 2-n represent another parameter of Q 1 and Q 2, respectively. And n is a dimensionless exponent. As a comparison, Nyquist plots of the NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst is also tested in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea at 0.4 V from 100 kHz to 10 mHz. It shows that the diameter of the impedance arc obtained on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst in the low-frequency region is smaller than that on the NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst, implying a lower electrochemical impedance of urea oxidation. The specific values of each component, fitted by ZSimDemo software, were exhibited in Table 2 . The electrochemical impedances of urea oxidation on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst at 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5 V were evaluated as 4.97, 3.50, and 2.41 Ω cm2 respectively. The smaller values of impedance confirmed the good conductivity and high performance of the prepared NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. 3.7 Assembling direct urea hydrogen peroxide fuel cell The prepared NiCo2S4@CS electrode was employed as the anode to assemble a direct urea hydrogen peroxide fuel cell (DUHPFC), in which a Pd/Ti plate electrode was adopted as the cathode. H2O2 is employed as an efficient and superior oxidant in the DUHPFC [63,64]. Fuel cell structure adopted in this work is the same as our previously reported work [32]. Nafion 117 membrane is used as a cation exchange membrane. Both anolyte (5 M KOH + 0.2 M urea) and catholyte (2 M H2SO4 + 1 M H2O2) were pumped into the anode and cathode chambers at a flow rate of 10 mL min−1. As a comparison, the NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst was also employed to assemble a DUHPFC. The polarization curve and power density curves of both anodes were exhibited in Fig. 7 (a). The open-circle potential of 0.84 V was obtained of the NiCo2S4@CS anode assembled DUHPFC, while this value was 0.75 V of the NiCo-precursor@CS anode assembled DUHPFC. Also, a higher power density of 7.68 mW cm−2 was obtained of the NiCo2S4@CS anode assembled DUHPFC which is higher than the value (5.72 mW cm−2) of NiCo-precursor@CS anode assembled DUHPFC at room temperature. The influence of temperature on the performance of NiCo2S4@CS anode assembled DUHPFC was displayed in Fig. 7(b). The open-circle potentials at 293.15, 313.15 and 333.15 K are 0.84, 0.85 and 0.87 V, respectively. With the increase of temperature from 293.15 K to 333.15 K, the power density increased from 7.68, 8.58 to 10.36 mW cm−2. The improved performance may be a result of the promoted diffusion coefficients and mass transfer of the reactants, as well as the faster kinetics of urea oxidation and H2O2 reduction at higher temperature [47]. Stability research of the NiCo2S4@CS anode assembled DUHPFC at different temperatures was shown in Fig. 7(c). During the 1.5 h tests at a current density of 15 mA cm−2, the voltage lost 9.4% at a temperature of 333.15 K and decreased by 8.3% at a temperature of 293.15 K. This phenomenon may be caused by the increased hydrolysis reaction of both urea and H2O2 at a higher temperature [47]. Therefore, a suitable temperature for good performance and low fuel/oxidant decomposition rate should be explored in practical applications. The DUHPFC performance with different anode catalysts in reported literature is compared in Table 3 . The prepared NiCo2S4@CS anode catalyst with a low price exhibited a comparable or higher performance when comparing with those reported works, revealing that NiCo2S4@CS is a promising anode to be applied in DUHPFC. 3.8 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation First-principles DFT calculations were conducted to gain more insights into the high performance of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. Fig. 8 (a) and (b) shows the optimized adsorption geometries of OH− and urea on the surface of carbon sponge modeled using a graphene sheet. The calculated OC distances (d) for the optimized adsorption geometries of OH− and urea on the surface of carbon sponge are 2.768 and 3.318 Å which are compared with the values of OH− and urea on the surface of NiCo2S4 in Table 4 . Here, crystalline NiCo2S4 (311) plane is considered because HRTEM and XRD show its preferential exposure. It can be seen that on the surface of NiCo2S4, the d values of H2NCONH2 Ni(NiCo2S4) and HONi(NiCo2S4) are much smaller than those of HOC(carbon sponge) and H2NCONH2 C(carbon sponge) which means easier to form a chemical bond interaction on the surface of NiCo2S4. In addition, the existence of Co is beneficial to the adsorption of OH− which may contribute to the improvement of the performance of NiCo2S4. In the adsorption geometry of urea on the surface of NiCo2S4, the urea molecules absorbed to Ni atom through the O atom which is consistent with the previous reports that Ni atoms are the active sites where urea oxidation is proposed to occur [49]. The formation of interfacial bonding between OH−/urea and NiCo2S4 surface can be further confirmed by the charge transfer at their interface as shown in Fig. 8(e) and (f). At the same time, the binding energies of OH− and urea molecules adsorbed on carbon sponge and NiCo2S4 were listed in Table 5 . 4 Conclusions In this work, three-dimensional multi-channel carbon sponge with low-cost is prepared by carbonized recycled polyurethane sponge. NiCo2S4 nanowires were successfully grown on the carbon sponge skeleton by two steps of hydrothermal treatment. NiCo2S4 nanowires provide a large specific surface area to the binder-free catalyst, which exhibits a good performance (635 mA cm−2 at 0.5 V) and stability (maintained 94.3% current density after 1800s CA tests) towards urea electrooxidation in 5 M KOH and 0.2 M urea. In addition, the higher performance of the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst than that of the NiCo-precursor@CS catalyst proves that sulfurization is an efficient method to improve the performance of Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst. The introducing of Co element significantly reduced the initial urea oxidation potential from 0.33 V to 0.14 V. Kinetic parameters research revealed an improved charge transfer rate and faster kinetics of urea electrooxidation on the NiCo2S4@CS catalyst. The prepared NiCo2S4@CS catalyst also possesses a large electrochemical active surface area (330.7 cm2), low activation energy (15.3 kJ mol−1) and small electrochemical impedance (2.41 Ω cm−2) of urea electrooxidation. At the same time, the NiCo2S4@CS anode assembled DUHPFC exhibited a higher peak power density of 10.36 mW cm−2 than NiCo-precursor@CS anode assembled DUHPFC (5.72 mW cm−2). After 5400 s tests, the NiCo2S4@CS anode assembled DUHPFC maintained a voltage of 91.2% of the initial voltage. We believe that this work offered a new option for the commercial application of DUHPFC by using low-cost and high-performance anode catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Urea oxidation is a significant reaction for utilizing urea-rich wastewater or human urine as sustainable power sources which can ease the water eutrophication while generate electricity. A direct urea-hydrogen peroxide fuel cell is a new kind of fuel cell employing urea as fuel and hydrogen peroxide as oxidant which possesses a larger cell voltage. Herein, this work tries to promote the kinetics process of urea oxidation by preparing low-cost and high-efficient NiCo2S4 nanowires modified carbon sponge electrode. The carbon sponge used in this work with a similar three-dimensional multi-channel structure to Ni foam, is prepared by carbonizing recycled polyurethane sponge which is also a process of recycling waste. The performance of the prepared catalyst in an alkaline solution is investigated in a three-electrode system. With the introduction of Co element to the catalyst, a reduced initial urea oxidation potential and a high performance are obtained. Furthermore, a direct urea-hydrogen peroxide fuel cell is assembled using the NiCo2S4 nanowires modified carbon sponge anode. Results indicate that the prepared catalyst provides a chance to solve the current problems that hinder the development of urea electrooxidation (high initial urea oxidation potential, low performance, and high electrode costs).
